trans-unit.source: Writer
trans-unit.target: Writer

trans-unit.source: Writes a dataset to web URLs or to various forms of cloud-based storage in Azure, such as tables, blobs, and SQL Server databases
trans-unit.target: Writes a dataset to web URLs or to various forms of cloud-based storage in Azure, such as tables, blobs, and SQL Server databases

trans-unit.source: Category: <legacyLink xlink:href="F1050CE4-218A-4304-A4A7-57832BE4CDE0" xmlns:xlink="http://www.w3.org/1999/xlink">Data Input and Output</legacyLink>
trans-unit.target: Category: <legacyLink xlink:href="F1050CE4-218A-4304-A4A7-57832BE4CDE0" xmlns:xlink="http://www.w3.org/1999/xlink">Data Input and Output</legacyLink>

trans-unit.source: Module Overview
trans-unit.target: Module Overview

trans-unit.source: You can use the <ui>Writer</ui> module to save data from your experiments into data management services outside Azure Machine Learning Studio.
trans-unit.target: You can use the <ui>Writer</ui> module to save data from your experiments into data management services outside Azure Machine Learning Studio.

trans-unit.source: <ui>Writer</ui> supports these storage destinations:
trans-unit.target: <ui>Writer</ui> supports these storage destinations:

trans-unit.source: <legacyLink xlink:href="#bkmk_HiveQuery" xmlns:xlink="http://www.w3.org/1999/xlink">Hive Query</legacyLink>.
trans-unit.target: <legacyLink xlink:href="#bkmk_HiveQuery" xmlns:xlink="http://www.w3.org/1999/xlink">Hive Query</legacyLink>.

trans-unit.source: Writes data to a Hive table in an HDInsight Hadoop cluster.
trans-unit.target: Writes data to a Hive table in an HDInsight Hadoop cluster.

trans-unit.source: <legacyLink xlink:href="#bkmk_AzureTable" xmlns:xlink="http://www.w3.org/1999/xlink">Azure table</legacyLink>.
trans-unit.target: <legacyLink xlink:href="#bkmk_AzureTable" xmlns:xlink="http://www.w3.org/1999/xlink">Azure table</legacyLink>.

trans-unit.source: Saves data to the Table service in Azure.
trans-unit.target: Saves data to the Table service in Azure.

trans-unit.source: Table service in Azure is good for storing large amounts of data.
trans-unit.target: Table service in Azure is good for storing large amounts of data.

trans-unit.source: It provides a flexible, non-relational (NoSQL), massively-scalable, inexpensive, and highly available storage solution.
trans-unit.target: It provides a flexible, non-relational (NoSQL), massively-scalable, inexpensive, and highly available storage solution.

trans-unit.source: <legacyLink xlink:href="#bkmk_AzureBlob" xmlns:xlink="http://www.w3.org/1999/xlink">Azure blob storage</legacyLink>.
trans-unit.target: <legacyLink xlink:href="#bkmk_AzureBlob" xmlns:xlink="http://www.w3.org/1999/xlink">Azure blob storage</legacyLink>.

trans-unit.source: Saves data to the Blob service in Azure.
trans-unit.target: Saves data to the Blob service in Azure.

trans-unit.source: This option is useful for images, unstructured text, or binary data.
trans-unit.target: This option is useful for images, unstructured text, or binary data.

trans-unit.source: Data in the Blob service can be shared publicly or saved in secured application data stores.
trans-unit.target: Data in the Blob service can be shared publicly or saved in secured application data stores.

trans-unit.source: With this option, you can access your data from anywhere in the world via HTTP or HTTPS.
trans-unit.target: With this option, you can access your data from anywhere in the world via HTTP or HTTPS.

trans-unit.source: <legacyLink xlink:href="#bkmk_SQLAzure" xmlns:xlink="http://www.w3.org/1999/xlink">Azure SQL database</legacyLink>.
trans-unit.target: <legacyLink xlink:href="#bkmk_SQLAzure" xmlns:xlink="http://www.w3.org/1999/xlink">Azure SQL database</legacyLink>.

trans-unit.source: Saves data to Azure SQL databases.
trans-unit.target: Saves data to Azure SQL databases.

trans-unit.source: This option is particularly good for fast access to smaller amounts of frequently used information, such as data lookup tables or data dictionaries.
trans-unit.target: This option is particularly good for fast access to smaller amounts of frequently used information, such as data lookup tables or data dictionaries.

trans-unit.source: Storage in Azure SQL databases is slightly more expensive than using table or blobs in Azure, and there may be limits on the amount of data that you can store in a database.
trans-unit.target: Storage in Azure SQL databases is slightly more expensive than using table or blobs in Azure, and there may be limits on the amount of data that you can store in a database.

trans-unit.source: However, there are no transaction fees against SQL databases.
trans-unit.target: However, there are no transaction fees against SQL databases.

trans-unit.source: How to Configure Writer
trans-unit.target: How to Configure Writer

trans-unit.source: There are multiple options for <ui>Writer</ui>, depending on the destination you are saving to and whether authentication is required.
trans-unit.target: There are multiple options for <ui>Writer</ui>, depending on the destination you are saving to and whether authentication is required.

trans-unit.source: Hive Query
trans-unit.target: Hive Query

trans-unit.source: Use this option to save your dataset or results into a Hive table in the HDInsight cluster.
trans-unit.target: Use this option to save your dataset or results into a Hive table in the HDInsight cluster.

trans-unit.source: To define the destination of the output data, set the following parameters for the destination Hadoop cluster:
trans-unit.target: To define the destination of the output data, set the following parameters for the destination Hadoop cluster:

trans-unit.source: Hive table name
trans-unit.target: Hive table name

trans-unit.source: Type the name of the Hive table that will store the dataset.
trans-unit.target: Type the name of the Hive table that will store the dataset.

trans-unit.source: HCatalog server URI
trans-unit.target: HCatalog server URI

trans-unit.source: Type the name of your cluster, in the format <your cluster name>.azurehdinsight.net.
trans-unit.target: Type the name of your cluster, in the format <your cluster name>.azurehdinsight.net.

trans-unit.source: Hadoop user account name
trans-unit.target: Hadoop user account name

trans-unit.source: Type the Hadoop user account name that you specified when you provisioned the cluster.
trans-unit.target: Type the Hadoop user account name that you specified when you provisioned the cluster.

trans-unit.source: Hadoop user account password
trans-unit.target: Hadoop user account password

trans-unit.source: Type the credentials that you provided when you provisioned the cluster.
trans-unit.target: Type the credentials that you provided when you provisioned the cluster.

trans-unit.source: For more information, see <externalLink><linkText>Provision Hadoop clusters in HDInsight</linkText><linkUri>http://azure.microsoft.com/documentation/articles/hdinsight-provision-clusters/</linkUri></externalLink>.
trans-unit.target: For more information, see <externalLink><linkText>Provision Hadoop clusters in HDInsight</linkText><linkUri>http://azure.microsoft.com/documentation/articles/hdinsight-provision-clusters/</linkUri></externalLink>.

trans-unit.source: Location of output data
trans-unit.target: Location of output data

trans-unit.source: Specify whether the data should be stored in a Hadoop distributed file system (HDFS) or in Azure.
trans-unit.target: Specify whether the data should be stored in a Hadoop distributed file system (HDFS) or in Azure.

trans-unit.source: HDFS
trans-unit.target: HDFS

trans-unit.source: To save your data into HDFS, specify the <ui>HDFS server URI</ui>.
trans-unit.target: To save your data into HDFS, specify the <ui>HDFS server URI</ui>.

trans-unit.source: Be sure to use the HDInsight cluster name without the HTTPS:// prefix.
trans-unit.target: Be sure to use the HDInsight cluster name without the HTTPS:// prefix.

trans-unit.source: Azure
trans-unit.target: Azure

trans-unit.source: If you save your data in Azure, you must specify the following:
trans-unit.target: If you save your data in Azure, you must specify the following:

trans-unit.source: Azure Storage account name
trans-unit.target: Azure Storage account name

trans-unit.source: Use the account that was used to provision the Hadoop cluster.
trans-unit.target: Use the account that was used to provision the Hadoop cluster.

trans-unit.source: Azure Storage access key
trans-unit.target: Azure Storage access key

trans-unit.source: Copy and paste the key that is provided for accessing the storage account.
trans-unit.target: Copy and paste the key that is provided for accessing the storage account.

trans-unit.source: If you don’t have an access key, see <externalLink><linkText>How to regenerate storage access keys</linkText><linkUri>http://azure.microsoft.com/documentation/articles/storage-manage-storage-account/</linkUri></externalLink>.
trans-unit.target: If you don’t have an access key, see <externalLink><linkText>How to regenerate storage access keys</linkText><linkUri>http://azure.microsoft.com/documentation/articles/storage-manage-storage-account/</linkUri></externalLink>.

trans-unit.source: Azure Storage container name
trans-unit.target: Azure Storage container name

trans-unit.source: You must use the <legacyBold>default container</legacyBold> of the cluster.
trans-unit.target: You must use the <legacyBold>default container</legacyBold> of the cluster.

trans-unit.source: Typically, you use the default settings to create a container when you provision a cluster.
trans-unit.target: Typically, you use the default settings to create a container when you provision a cluster.

trans-unit.source: If you created your cluster by using the default settings, a container with the same name as the cluster is created.
trans-unit.target: If you created your cluster by using the default settings, a container with the same name as the cluster is created.

trans-unit.source: This is the storage container name for the cluster.
trans-unit.target: This is the storage container name for the cluster.

trans-unit.source: However, if you created your cluster by using the <ui>CUSTOM CREATE</ui> option, you were given two options for selecting the default container:
trans-unit.target: However, if you created your cluster by using the <ui>CUSTOM CREATE</ui> option, you were given two options for selecting the default container:

trans-unit.source: If you selected an existing container, it is used as the storage container name for the cluster.
trans-unit.target: If you selected an existing container, it is used as the storage container name for the cluster.

trans-unit.source: If you used the <ui>Create default container</ui> option, a container with the same name as the cluster is created, and this will be the storage container name for the cluster.
trans-unit.target: If you used the <ui>Create default container</ui> option, a container with the same name as the cluster is created, and this will be the storage container name for the cluster.

trans-unit.source: Azure Table
trans-unit.target: Azure Table

trans-unit.source: Use this option to save data into a table in Azure Storage.
trans-unit.target: Use this option to save data into a table in Azure Storage.

trans-unit.source: The Table service is the data management service in Azure Storage that stores large amounts of structured, non-relational data.
trans-unit.target: The Table service is the data management service in Azure Storage that stores large amounts of structured, non-relational data.

trans-unit.source: The Table service is a NoSQL data store that accesses authenticated calls from inside and outside Azure.
trans-unit.target: The Table service is a NoSQL data store that accesses authenticated calls from inside and outside Azure.

trans-unit.source: The options in <ui>Writer</ui> change depending on whether you are writing data to a public shared resource or to a private storage account that requires login credentials.
trans-unit.target: The options in <ui>Writer</ui> change depending on whether you are writing data to a public shared resource or to a private storage account that requires login credentials.

trans-unit.source: Azure Table - Public or SAS
trans-unit.target: Azure Table - Public or SAS

trans-unit.source: If you are saving data to a table that can be publicly accessed, or if you are using a shared access signature (SAS) URI for authentication, you do not need additional credentials, because both options contain all the information in the URL string that is needed for download and authentication.
trans-unit.target: If you are saving data to a table that can be publicly accessed, or if you are using a shared access signature (SAS) URI for authentication, you do not need additional credentials, because both options contain all the information in the URL string that is needed for download and authentication.

trans-unit.source: An SAS URL is a time-bound access URL that contains all the information needed for the transfer.
trans-unit.target: An SAS URL is a time-bound access URL that contains all the information needed for the transfer.

trans-unit.source: You can generate an SAS URL for a storage account by using utilities such as Azure Storage Explorer.
trans-unit.target: You can generate an SAS URL for a storage account by using utilities such as Azure Storage Explorer.

trans-unit.source: To access the data, provide the URL as follows:
trans-unit.target: To access the data, provide the URL as follows:

trans-unit.source: SAS Table URI
trans-unit.target: SAS Table URI

trans-unit.source: Type the SAS URL for the storage account.
trans-unit.target: Type the SAS URL for the storage account.

trans-unit.source: Partition key
trans-unit.target: Partition key

trans-unit.source: Use the <ui>Column Selector</ui> to specify the column that should be used for partitioning the saved dataset for the table in Azure Storage.
trans-unit.target: Use the <ui>Column Selector</ui> to specify the column that should be used for partitioning the saved dataset for the table in Azure Storage.

trans-unit.source: Tables in Azure are partitioned to support load balancing across storage nodes.
trans-unit.target: Tables in Azure are partitioned to support load balancing across storage nodes.

trans-unit.source: All table entities are organized by partition, and you must include the <embeddedLabel>PartitionKey</embeddedLabel> property in every insert, update, and delete operation.
trans-unit.target: All table entities are organized by partition, and you must include the <embeddedLabel>PartitionKey</embeddedLabel> property in every insert, update, and delete operation.

trans-unit.source: For more information about partitioning tables in Azure Storage, see <externalLink><linkText>Understanding the Table Service Data Model</linkText><linkUri>https://msdn.microsoft.com/library/azure/dd179338.aspx</linkUri></externalLink>.
trans-unit.target: For more information about partitioning tables in Azure Storage, see <externalLink><linkText>Understanding the Table Service Data Model</linkText><linkUri>https://msdn.microsoft.com/library/azure/dd179338.aspx</linkUri></externalLink>.

trans-unit.source: Azure table row key
trans-unit.target: Azure table row key

trans-unit.source: Use the <ui>Column Selector</ui> to specify the column that should be used for the <embeddedLabel>RowKey</embeddedLabel> property.
trans-unit.target: Use the <ui>Column Selector</ui> to specify the column that should be used for the <embeddedLabel>RowKey</embeddedLabel> property.

trans-unit.source: An entity in table storage has the following system properties, which are required for every entity in a table:
trans-unit.target: An entity in table storage has the following system properties, which are required for every entity in a table:

trans-unit.source: PartitionKey property
trans-unit.target: PartitionKey property

trans-unit.source: RowKey property
trans-unit.target: RowKey property

trans-unit.source: Timestamp property
trans-unit.target: Timestamp property

trans-unit.source: The developer is responsible for inserting and updating the values of the <embeddedLabel>PartitionKey</embeddedLabel> and <embeddedLabel>RowKey</embeddedLabel> properties.
trans-unit.target: The developer is responsible for inserting and updating the values of the <embeddedLabel>PartitionKey</embeddedLabel> and <embeddedLabel>RowKey</embeddedLabel> properties.

trans-unit.source: The server manages the value of the <embeddedLabel>Timestamp</embeddedLabel> property, which cannot be modified.
trans-unit.target: The server manages the value of the <embeddedLabel>Timestamp</embeddedLabel> property, which cannot be modified.

trans-unit.source: Azure table origin columns
trans-unit.target: Azure table origin columns

trans-unit.source: Use the <ui>Column Selector</ui> to specify any additional columns from the dataset that you want to save to the Table service in Azure Storage.
trans-unit.target: Use the <ui>Column Selector</ui> to specify any additional columns from the dataset that you want to save to the Table service in Azure Storage.

trans-unit.source: Azure table destination columns
trans-unit.target: Azure table destination columns

trans-unit.source: Provide a comma-separated list of column names to use in the destination table.
trans-unit.target: Provide a comma-separated list of column names to use in the destination table.

trans-unit.source: Azure table write mode
trans-unit.target: Azure table write mode

trans-unit.source: Specify how you want the new rows to be combined with existing data in the Table service in Azure Storage.
trans-unit.target: Specify how you want the new rows to be combined with existing data in the Table service in Azure Storage.

trans-unit.source: <ui>Writer</ui> provides these options, given that each row consists of an entity:
trans-unit.target: <ui>Writer</ui> provides these options, given that each row consists of an entity:

trans-unit.source: <legacyItalic><ui>Insert</ui></legacyItalic>: The <languageKeyword>Insert Entity</languageKeyword> operation inserts a new entity with a unique primary key, which is formed from a combination of the <embeddedLabel>PartitionKey</embeddedLabel> and the <embeddedLabel>RowKey</embeddedLabel> properties.
trans-unit.target: <legacyItalic><ui>Insert</ui></legacyItalic>: The <languageKeyword>Insert Entity</languageKeyword> operation inserts a new entity with a unique primary key, which is formed from a combination of the <embeddedLabel>PartitionKey</embeddedLabel> and the <embeddedLabel>RowKey</embeddedLabel> properties.

trans-unit.source: <legacyItalic><ui>Merge</ui></legacyItalic>: The <languageKeyword>Merge Entity</languageKeyword> operation updates an existing entity by updating the entity's properties.
trans-unit.target: <legacyItalic><ui>Merge</ui></legacyItalic>: The <languageKeyword>Merge Entity</languageKeyword> operation updates an existing entity by updating the entity's properties.

trans-unit.source: This operation does not replace the existing entity.
trans-unit.target: This operation does not replace the existing entity.

trans-unit.source: <legacyItalic><ui>Replace</ui></legacyItalic>: The <languageKeyword>Update Entity</languageKeyword> operation replaces the contents of the given entity in a table.
trans-unit.target: <legacyItalic><ui>Replace</ui></legacyItalic>: The <languageKeyword>Update Entity</languageKeyword> operation replaces the contents of the given entity in a table.

trans-unit.source: <legacyItalic><ui>InsertOrReplace</ui></legacyItalic>: The <languageKeyword>InsertOrReplace Entity</languageKeyword> operation inserts the entity if the entity does not exist.
trans-unit.target: <legacyItalic><ui>InsertOrReplace</ui></legacyItalic>: The <languageKeyword>InsertOrReplace Entity</languageKeyword> operation inserts the entity if the entity does not exist.

trans-unit.source: If the entity exists, it replaces the existing one.
trans-unit.target: If the entity exists, it replaces the existing one.

trans-unit.source: <legacyItalic><ui>InsertOrMerge</ui></legacyItalic>: The <languageKeyword>InsertOrMerge Entity</languageKeyword> operation inserts the entity if the entity does not exist.
trans-unit.target: <legacyItalic><ui>InsertOrMerge</ui></legacyItalic>: The <languageKeyword>InsertOrMerge Entity</languageKeyword> operation inserts the entity if the entity does not exist.

trans-unit.source: If the entity exists, it merges the provided entity properties with the already existing ones.
trans-unit.target: If the entity exists, it merges the provided entity properties with the already existing ones.

trans-unit.source: For more information about how to work with entities in the Table service in Azure Storage, see <externalLink><linkText>Table Service Concepts</linkText><linkUri>https://msdn.microsoft.com/library/azure/dd179463.aspx</linkUri></externalLink>.
trans-unit.target: For more information about how to work with entities in the Table service in Azure Storage, see <externalLink><linkText>Table Service Concepts</linkText><linkUri>https://msdn.microsoft.com/library/azure/dd179463.aspx</linkUri></externalLink>.

trans-unit.source: Azure Table - Account
trans-unit.target: Azure Table - Account

trans-unit.source: To use <ui>Writer</ui> to save data into a secured table, you must provide the following additional information about the source, account, and credentials:
trans-unit.target: To use <ui>Writer</ui> to save data into a secured table, you must provide the following additional information about the source, account, and credentials:

trans-unit.source: Table account name
trans-unit.target: Table account name

trans-unit.source: The name of the account that contains the table you want to save data into.
trans-unit.target: The name of the account that contains the table you want to save data into.

trans-unit.source: Table account key
trans-unit.target: Table account key

trans-unit.source: The storage access key associated with the account.
trans-unit.target: The storage access key associated with the account.

trans-unit.source: Table name
trans-unit.target: Table name

trans-unit.source: The name of the table that you want to save the data into.
trans-unit.target: The name of the table that you want to save the data into.

trans-unit.source: Azure Blob Storage
trans-unit.target: Azure Blob Storage

trans-unit.source: Use this option to save data into a blob in Azure storage.
trans-unit.target: Use this option to save data into a blob in Azure storage.

trans-unit.source: The Blob service is for storing large amounts of data that can be accessed from anywhere via HTTP or HTTPS.
trans-unit.target: The Blob service is for storing large amounts of data that can be accessed from anywhere via HTTP or HTTPS.

trans-unit.source: The options in <ui>Writer</ui> change depending on whether you are saving data to a public blob or writing to a private storage account that requires login credentials.
trans-unit.target: The options in <ui>Writer</ui> change depending on whether you are saving data to a public blob or writing to a private storage account that requires login credentials.

trans-unit.source: Azure Blob Storage - Public or SAS
trans-unit.target: Azure Blob Storage - Public or SAS

trans-unit.source: If you save data into a blob that is public or if you authenticate by using an SAS URL, you do not need additional credentials because both options contain all the information in the URL string that is needed for download and authentication.
trans-unit.target: If you save data into a blob that is public or if you authenticate by using an SAS URL, you do not need additional credentials because both options contain all the information in the URL string that is needed for download and authentication.

trans-unit.source: Simply provide the URL and specify the format as follows:
trans-unit.target: Simply provide the URL and specify the format as follows:

trans-unit.source: SAS URI for blob
trans-unit.target: SAS URI for blob

trans-unit.source: An SAS URL is a time-bound access URL that contains all the information needed for the blob transfer.
trans-unit.target: An SAS URL is a time-bound access URL that contains all the information needed for the blob transfer.

trans-unit.source: You can generate an SAS URL for a storage account by using utilities such as Azure Storage Explorer.
trans-unit.target: You can generate an SAS URL for a storage account by using utilities such as Azure Storage Explorer.

trans-unit.source: File format for SAS file
trans-unit.target: File format for SAS file

trans-unit.source: Specify the format of the data that you will save by using SAS authentication.
trans-unit.target: Specify the format of the data that you will save by using SAS authentication.

trans-unit.source: The supported formats are CSV, TSV, and ARFF.
trans-unit.target: The supported formats are CSV, TSV, and ARFF.

trans-unit.source: Write SAS header row
trans-unit.target: Write SAS header row

trans-unit.source: If you write data to the Blob service in Azure Storage by using an SAS URL, you can specify that the first line be treated as a header.
trans-unit.target: If you write data to the Blob service in Azure Storage by using an SAS URL, you can specify that the first line be treated as a header.

trans-unit.source: For more information about shared access signatures, see <externalLink><linkText>Shared Access Signatures Part 1: Understanding the SAS Model</linkText><linkUri>http://azure.microsoft.com/documentation/articles/storage-dotnet-shared-access-signature-part-1/</linkUri></externalLink>.
trans-unit.target: For more information about shared access signatures, see <externalLink><linkText>Shared Access Signatures Part 1: Understanding the SAS Model</linkText><linkUri>http://azure.microsoft.com/documentation/articles/storage-dotnet-shared-access-signature-part-1/</linkUri></externalLink>.

trans-unit.source: Azure Blob Storage - Account
trans-unit.target: Azure Blob Storage - Account

trans-unit.source: To use <ui>Writer</ui> to save data into a secured table, you must provide the following information about the source, account, and credentials:
trans-unit.target: To use <ui>Writer</ui> to save data into a secured table, you must provide the following information about the source, account, and credentials:

trans-unit.source: Azure account name
trans-unit.target: Azure account name

trans-unit.source: The name of the storage account where the blob was created.
trans-unit.target: The name of the storage account where the blob was created.

trans-unit.source: For example, assuming the full URL of the storage account is <userInputLocalizable>http://myliveaccount.blob.core.windows.net</userInputLocalizable>, you would type <userInputLocalizable>myliveaccount</userInputLocalizable>.
trans-unit.target: For example, assuming the full URL of the storage account is <userInputLocalizable>http://myliveaccount.blob.core.windows.net</userInputLocalizable>, you would type <userInputLocalizable>myliveaccount</userInputLocalizable>.

trans-unit.source: Azure account key
trans-unit.target: Azure account key

trans-unit.source: The storage access key that is associated with the account.
trans-unit.target: The storage access key that is associated with the account.

trans-unit.source: If you do not know the access key, open the Azure portal, select the account, and click <ui>Manage Access Keys</ui> to view the current keys or generate a new set of keys.
trans-unit.target: If you do not know the access key, open the Azure portal, select the account, and click <ui>Manage Access Keys</ui> to view the current keys or generate a new set of keys.

trans-unit.source: Path to blob beginning with container
trans-unit.target: Path to blob beginning with container

trans-unit.source: Type an identifier for the new blob, using this format: <container name>/<blob_name>.
trans-unit.target: Type an identifier for the new blob, using this format: <container name>/<blob_name>.

trans-unit.source: For example, suppose your account is <userInputLocalizable>myliveaccount</userInputLocalizable>, and you have created a container named <userInputLocalizable>trainingdata</userInputLocalizable>.
trans-unit.target: For example, suppose your account is <userInputLocalizable>myliveaccount</userInputLocalizable>, and you have created a container named <userInputLocalizable>trainingdata</userInputLocalizable>.

trans-unit.source: You want to write a transformed dataset to a blob using the filename, <userInputLocalizable>newdata</userInputLocalizable>.
trans-unit.target: You want to write a transformed dataset to a blob using the filename, <userInputLocalizable>newdata</userInputLocalizable>.

trans-unit.source: For the path, type <userInputLocalizable>trainingdata/newdata</userInputLocalizable>.
trans-unit.target: For the path, type <userInputLocalizable>trainingdata/newdata</userInputLocalizable>.

trans-unit.source: The full URL to the resulting file would be as follows:
trans-unit.target: The full URL to the resulting file would be as follows:

trans-unit.source: http://myliveaccount.blob.core.windows.net/trainingdata/newdata
trans-unit.target: http://myliveaccount.blob.core.windows.net/trainingdata/newdata

trans-unit.source: Azure blob storage write mode
trans-unit.target: Azure blob storage write mode

trans-unit.source: Specify how you want the data to be handled when there is existing data in the blob in Azure Storage.
trans-unit.target: Specify how you want the data to be handled when there is existing data in the blob in Azure Storage.

trans-unit.source: <ui>Writer</ui> provides these options:
trans-unit.target: <ui>Writer</ui> provides these options:

trans-unit.source: <legacyItalic><ui>Error</ui></legacyItalic>: If there is an existing blob of this name, do not save the data to blob, and return an error message.
trans-unit.target: <legacyItalic><ui>Error</ui></legacyItalic>: If there is an existing blob of this name, do not save the data to blob, and return an error message.

trans-unit.source: <legacyItalic><ui>Overwrite</ui></legacyItalic>: Silently overwrite any existing data in the blob.
trans-unit.target: <legacyItalic><ui>Overwrite</ui></legacyItalic>: Silently overwrite any existing data in the blob.

trans-unit.source: An error will still be returned if the blob cannot be created, or if the container cannot be found.
trans-unit.target: An error will still be returned if the blob cannot be created, or if the container cannot be found.

trans-unit.source: However, an error will not be returned if a blob of this name already exists.
trans-unit.target: However, an error will not be returned if a blob of this name already exists.

trans-unit.source: File format for blob file
trans-unit.target: File format for blob file

trans-unit.source: When writing to a blob in Azure Storage, you can use any of these formats: CSV, TSV, or ARFF.
trans-unit.target: When writing to a blob in Azure Storage, you can use any of these formats: CSV, TSV, or ARFF.

trans-unit.source: If you save data in the CSV or TSV format, use the <ui>Write blob header row</ui> option to indicate that the first row of the data is a header row.
trans-unit.target: If you save data in the CSV or TSV format, use the <ui>Write blob header row</ui> option to indicate that the first row of the data is a header row.

trans-unit.source: Azure SQL Database
trans-unit.target: Azure SQL Database

trans-unit.source: Use this option to save data to a SQL database in Azure.
trans-unit.target: Use this option to save data to a SQL database in Azure.

trans-unit.source: If you run the experiment again, you will add the same rows to the table in the SQL database each time.
trans-unit.target: If you run the experiment again, you will add the same rows to the table in the SQL database each time.

trans-unit.source: You can use a <languageKeyword>TRUNCATE</languageKeyword> statement to clear the table before re-running an experiment.
trans-unit.target: You can use a <languageKeyword>TRUNCATE</languageKeyword> statement to clear the table before re-running an experiment.

trans-unit.source: Database server name
trans-unit.target: Database server name

trans-unit.source: Type the server name that is generated by Azure.
trans-unit.target: Type the server name that is generated by Azure.

trans-unit.source: Typically it has the form <codeInline>%%amp;lt;generated_identifier%%amp;gt;.database.windows.net</codeInline>.
trans-unit.target: Typically it has the form <codeInline>%%amp;lt;generated_identifier%%amp;gt;.database.windows.net</codeInline>.

trans-unit.source: Database name
trans-unit.target: Database name

trans-unit.source: Type the name of a database on the server you just specified.
trans-unit.target: Type the name of a database on the server you just specified.

trans-unit.source: Server user account name
trans-unit.target: Server user account name

trans-unit.source: Type the user name of an account that has <legacyBold>write</legacyBold> permissions for the database.
trans-unit.target: Type the user name of an account that has <legacyBold>write</legacyBold> permissions for the database.

trans-unit.source: Server user account password
trans-unit.target: Server user account password

trans-unit.source: Provide the password for the specified user account.
trans-unit.target: Provide the password for the specified user account.

trans-unit.source: Accept any server certificate (insecure)
trans-unit.target: Accept any server certificate (insecure)

trans-unit.source: Select this option if you don’t want to view the certificate.
trans-unit.target: Select this option if you don’t want to view the certificate.

trans-unit.source: Comma-separated list of columns to be saved
trans-unit.target: Comma-separated list of columns to be saved

trans-unit.source: Provide a list of the dataset or result columns that you want to output.
trans-unit.target: Provide a list of the dataset or result columns that you want to output.

trans-unit.source: All column names are case sensitive.
trans-unit.target: All column names are case sensitive.

trans-unit.source: Moreover, the number of columns you provide for this parameter must be the same as the columns that you list using the option, <ui>Comma-separated list of datatable columns query</ui>.
trans-unit.target: Moreover, the number of columns you provide for this parameter must be the same as the columns that you list using the option, <ui>Comma-separated list of datatable columns query</ui>.

trans-unit.source: Data table name
trans-unit.target: Data table name

trans-unit.source: Specify the name of the data table.
trans-unit.target: Specify the name of the data table.

trans-unit.source: Comma-separated list of datatable columns query
trans-unit.target: Comma-separated list of datatable columns query

trans-unit.source: Specify the column names to use in the new table.
trans-unit.target: Specify the column names to use in the new table.

trans-unit.source: The column names can be different from the ones in the source dataset, but you must list the same number of columns here that you define for the output table.
trans-unit.target: The column names can be different from the ones in the source dataset, but you must list the same number of columns here that you define for the output table.

trans-unit.source: Number of rows written per SQL Azure operation
trans-unit.target: Number of rows written per SQL Azure operation

trans-unit.source: You can configure the number of rows that are written to a SQL database in one operation.
trans-unit.target: You can configure the number of rows that are written to a SQL database in one operation.

trans-unit.source: You might decide to adjust this value if you are writing very large rows.
trans-unit.target: You might decide to adjust this value if you are writing very large rows.

trans-unit.source: For more information, see <externalLink><linkText>Windows Azure SQL Database Connection Management</linkText><linkUri>http://social.technet.microsoft.com/wiki/contents/articles/1541.windows-azure-sql-database-connection-management.aspx</linkUri></externalLink>.
trans-unit.target: For more information, see <externalLink><linkText>Windows Azure SQL Database Connection Management</linkText><linkUri>http://social.technet.microsoft.com/wiki/contents/articles/1541.windows-azure-sql-database-connection-management.aspx</linkUri></externalLink>.

trans-unit.source: Example
trans-unit.target: Example

trans-unit.source: For examples of how to use <ui>Writer</ui> in an experiment, see this sample experiment in the <externalLink><linkText>Model Gallery</linkText><linkUri>http://gallery.azureml.net/</linkUri></externalLink>:
trans-unit.target: For examples of how to use <ui>Writer</ui> in an experiment, see this sample experiment in the <externalLink><linkText>Model Gallery</linkText><linkUri>http://gallery.azureml.net/</linkUri></externalLink>:

trans-unit.source: The <externalLink><linkText>Anomaly Detection sample</linkText><linkUri>http://go.microsoft.com/fwlink/?LinkId=526066</linkUri></externalLink> uses <ui>Writer</ui> to save results.
trans-unit.target: The <externalLink><linkText>Anomaly Detection sample</linkText><linkUri>http://go.microsoft.com/fwlink/?LinkId=526066</linkUri></externalLink> uses <ui>Writer</ui> to save results.

trans-unit.source: The <externalLink><linkText>Text Classification</linkText><linkUri>http://gallery.azureml.net/Experiment/f43e79f47d8a4219bf8613d271ea2c45</linkUri></externalLink> sample uses <ui>Writer</ui> to save intermediate results and then uses <link xlink:href="4e1b0fe6-aded-4b3f-a36f-39b8862b9004" xmlns:xlink="http://www.w3.org/1999/xlink">Reader</link> to get them from storage for later steps in the experiment.
trans-unit.target: The <externalLink><linkText>Text Classification</linkText><linkUri>http://gallery.azureml.net/Experiment/f43e79f47d8a4219bf8613d271ea2c45</linkUri></externalLink> sample uses <ui>Writer</ui> to save intermediate results and then uses <link xlink:href="4e1b0fe6-aded-4b3f-a36f-39b8862b9004" xmlns:xlink="http://www.w3.org/1999/xlink">Reader</link> to get them from storage for later steps in the experiment.

trans-unit.source: Technical Notes
trans-unit.target: Technical Notes

trans-unit.source: Please be aware of the following known issues:
trans-unit.target: Please be aware of the following known issues:

trans-unit.source: Currently, if you select HDFS as the location to save output data, this error message is returned: “Microsoft.Analytics.Exceptions.ErrorMapping+ModuleException.”
trans-unit.target: Currently, if you select HDFS as the location to save output data, this error message is returned: “Microsoft.Analytics.Exceptions.ErrorMapping+ModuleException.”

trans-unit.source: If you select Azure as the location to output your data, sometimes there are errors when writing to the specified table—instead, the data is written to a blob in the container that you specified under the storage account name.
trans-unit.target: If you select Azure as the location to output your data, sometimes there are errors when writing to the specified table—instead, the data is written to a blob in the container that you specified under the storage account name.

trans-unit.source: The ability to save a blob into a specified Hive table is not working.
trans-unit.target: The ability to save a blob into a specified Hive table is not working.

trans-unit.source: Avoid using a Hive table in HDInsight for writing results.
trans-unit.target: Avoid using a Hive table in HDInsight for writing results.

trans-unit.source: Please specify data destination
trans-unit.target: Please specify data destination

trans-unit.source: List
trans-unit.target: List

trans-unit.source: DataSourceOrSink
trans-unit.target: DataSourceOrSink

trans-unit.source: Blob service in Azure Storage
trans-unit.target: Blob service in Azure Storage

trans-unit.source: Data destination can be a file in the Blob service or Table service, a SQL database, or a Hive table.
trans-unit.target: Data destination can be a file in the Blob service or Table service, a SQL database, or a Hive table.

trans-unit.source: Exceptions
trans-unit.target: Exceptions

trans-unit.source: Exception
trans-unit.target: Exception

trans-unit.source: Description
trans-unit.target: Description

trans-unit.source: An exception occurs when attempting to create a file or blob that already exists.
trans-unit.target: An exception occurs when attempting to create a file or blob that already exists.

trans-unit.source: An exception occurs if one or more specified columns of the dataset couldn't be found.
trans-unit.target: An exception occurs if one or more specified columns of the dataset couldn't be found.

trans-unit.source: An exception occurs when two objects have to be of the same size, but they are not.
trans-unit.target: An exception occurs when two objects have to be of the same size, but they are not.

trans-unit.source: An exception occurs if the container name in Azure Storage is specified incorrectly.
trans-unit.target: An exception occurs if the container name in Azure Storage is specified incorrectly.

trans-unit.source: An exception occurs if the storage access key for the Azure account is specified incorrectly.
trans-unit.target: An exception occurs if the storage access key for the Azure account is specified incorrectly.

trans-unit.source: An exception occurs if account name or storage access key for the Azure account is specified incorrectly.
trans-unit.target: An exception occurs if account name or storage access key for the Azure account is specified incorrectly.

trans-unit.source: An exception occurs if the provided credentials are incorrect.
trans-unit.target: An exception occurs if the provided credentials are incorrect.

trans-unit.source: An exception occurs if the input dataset is not valid.
trans-unit.target: An exception occurs if the input dataset is not valid.

trans-unit.source: An exception occurs when an invalid URI is passed.
trans-unit.target: An exception occurs when an invalid URI is passed.

trans-unit.source: An exception occurs if one or more inputs are null or empty.
trans-unit.target: An exception occurs if one or more inputs are null or empty.

trans-unit.source: Comparing Azure Table Storage and Azure SQL Database
trans-unit.target: Comparing Azure Table Storage and Azure SQL Database
